meta.rules: Academic passages by domain. Two per domain: one easier, one harder. MC: main idea, detail, inference, purpose. Use 'According to the passage' for factual stems. Key balance across A/B/C/D.

passages.title: The Water Cycle
passages.content:
The water cycle, also known as the hydrological cycle, describes the continuous movement of water on, above, and below the surface of the Earth. Water changes state between liquid, vapour, and ice as it moves through the cycle.

Evaporation from oceans, lakes, and rivers adds water vapour to the atmosphere. Plants also release water vapour through a process called transpiration. When the water vapour rises and cools, it condenses to form clouds. Precipitation—rain, snow, sleet, or hail—returns water to the surface. Some of this water runs off into streams and rivers, eventually reaching the ocean. Another portion seeps into the ground and becomes groundwater, which may later emerge in springs or be taken up by plant roots.

The cycle has no real beginning or end, but scientists often start by describing the ocean, which holds about 97 percent of Earth's water. Solar energy drives evaporation, and gravity pulls precipitation downward. Human activities, such as irrigation and the building of reservoirs, can alter local water distribution, but the global cycle as a whole remains balanced. Understanding the water cycle is essential for managing freshwater resources and predicting the effects of climate change on rainfall and drought.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of the passage?
options: To compare different types of precipitation
To describe the continuous movement of water on Earth
To explain how plants use groundwater
To argue that human activities harm the water cycle
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on describing the water cycle: the continuous movement of water through evaporation, condensation, precipitation, runoff, and groundwater.

questions.text: According to the passage, what process do plants use to release water vapour into the atmosphere?
options: Evaporation
Condensation
Transpiration
Precipitation
questions.explanation: The passage states that plants release water vapour through a process called transpiration.

questions.text: According to the passage, where is most of Earth's water stored?
options: In the ocean
In rivers and streams
In the atmosphere as vapour
In groundwater
questions.explanation: The passage states that the ocean holds about 97 percent of Earth's water.

questions.text: The passage suggests that the global water cycle remains balanced despite human activities because
options: human activities only affect small areas
evaporation and precipitation always increase together
scientists have found ways to restore the balance
the cycle as a whole continues even when local distribution changes
questions.explanation: The passage says human activities can alter local water distribution, but the global cycle as a whole remains balanced.

passages.title: Plate Tectonics and Earthquake Zones
passages.content:
Earth's outer layer, the lithosphere, is broken into several large plates that move slowly over the underlying asthenosphere. This movement is driven by heat from the planet's interior. Where plates meet, they may pull apart, collide, or slide past one another. These boundaries are the primary sites of earthquakes and volcanic activity.

At divergent boundaries, such as the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, plates move apart and new crust forms from magma rising from below. At convergent boundaries, one plate may sink beneath another in a process called subduction, often forming deep ocean trenches and mountain ranges. Transform boundaries, where plates slide past each other, can produce large earthquakes when stress builds up and is suddenly released—as along the San Andreas Fault in California.

Scientists use the theory of plate tectonics to explain the distribution of volcanoes and earthquakes worldwide. Because plate boundaries are where the greatest stress accumulates, they are monitored closely for seismic hazard. Understanding plate motion also helps explain the long-term evolution of continents and ocean basins.

questions.text: What is the passage mainly about?
options: How mountains form
The movement of Earth's plates and its effects on earthquakes and volcanoes
The difference between the lithosphere and asthenosphere
How to predict earthquakes in California
questions.explanation: The passage describes plate tectonics—plate movement and boundaries—and links them to earthquakes and volcanic activity.

questions.text: According to the passage, what happens at divergent boundaries?
options: One plate sinks beneath another
Plates slide past each other
Plates move apart and new crust forms
Stress builds up and is released as earthquakes
questions.explanation: The passage states that at divergent boundaries, such as the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, plates move apart and new crust forms from magma.

questions.text: According to the passage, why are plate boundaries monitored closely?
options: To find new mineral deposits
To measure the speed of plate movement
Because they are where the greatest seismic hazard occurs
To study the asthenosphere
questions.explanation: The passage says plate boundaries are where the greatest stress accumulates and are therefore monitored for seismic hazard.

questions.text: The author mentions the San Andreas Fault in order to
options: compare it to the Mid-Atlantic Ridge
explain subduction
describe volcanic activity
illustrate earthquakes at transform boundaries
questions.explanation: The passage uses the San Andreas Fault as an example of a transform boundary where plates slide past each other and produce large earthquakes.

passages.title: How Groups Make Decisions
passages.content:
When people make decisions in groups, the outcome can differ from what any one person would choose alone. In some cases, groups discuss ideas and reach a better solution because they combine different viewpoints. In other cases, groups make riskier or more cautious decisions than individuals would.

One well-known effect is called group polarisation. After a group discusses a topic, members often end up holding more extreme views than they did at the start. If most people initially lean in one direction, discussion tends to push them further in that direction. Another effect is groupthink, when the desire for agreement leads the group to ignore doubts or outside information. Groupthink can lead to poor decisions because criticism is suppressed.

Researchers study these effects to understand how juries, committees, and organisations reach conclusions. Knowing about group polarisation and groupthink can help people design better meetings and encourage more careful decision-making.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of the passage?
options: To argue that individuals make better decisions than groups
To describe how group discussion can affect decisions
To explain how juries reach verdicts
To recommend longer meetings
questions.explanation: The passage describes how group discussion can lead to different outcomes, including group polarisation and groupthink.

questions.text: According to the passage, what is group polarisation?
options: When discussion pushes members toward more extreme views
When groups ignore outside information
When one person dominates the group
When groups take longer to decide
questions.explanation: The passage defines group polarisation as the tendency for members to hold more extreme views after discussion than at the start.

questions.text: According to the passage, why can groupthink lead to poor decisions?
options: Because groups are too large
Because members have different viewpoints
Because meetings are too short
Because the desire for agreement suppresses criticism
questions.explanation: The passage states that groupthink occurs when the desire for agreement leads the group to ignore doubts and suppress criticism.

questions.text: The passage suggests that understanding these effects is useful for
options: predicting the outcome of any vote
reducing the size of groups
avoiding discussion altogether
designing better meetings and decision-making processes
questions.explanation: The passage says knowing about group polarisation and groupthink can help people design better meetings and encourage more careful decision-making.

passages.title: Cognitive Dissonance
passages.content:
Cognitive dissonance is the discomfort people feel when they hold two conflicting beliefs or when their behaviour conflicts with their beliefs. According to the theory, first developed by Leon Festinger in the 1950s, people are motivated to reduce this discomfort. They may do so by changing one of the beliefs, changing their behaviour, or adding new information that makes the conflict seem less important.

For example, a person who values health but smokes might minimise the health risks of smoking, quit smoking, or decide that the pleasure of smoking outweighs the risk. How people reduce dissonance depends on how committed they are to their beliefs and how easy it is to change their behaviour. In some cases, people may even deny or distort evidence to protect their self-image.

Dissonance theory has been used to study decisions about consumer behaviour, political attitudes, and moral behaviour. Critics have noted that the theory is broad and that people sometimes tolerate inconsistency without obvious discomfort. Nevertheless, the idea that people seek consistency between their attitudes and actions remains influential in social psychology.

questions.text: What is the passage mainly about?
options: The life of Leon Festinger
Cognitive dissonance and how people reduce it
The health risks of smoking
Consumer behaviour and advertising
questions.explanation: The passage defines cognitive dissonance and explains how people reduce it by changing beliefs, behaviour, or adding information.

questions.text: According to the passage, how might a person who values health but smokes reduce dissonance?
options: By changing the belief, changing behaviour, or reweighing the conflict
By avoiding information about health
By joining a support group only
By blaming others for their habit
questions.explanation: The passage gives the example of minimising risk, quitting, or deciding pleasure outweighs risk—all ways of changing beliefs or behaviour or reweighing the conflict.

questions.text: According to the passage, what have critics said about dissonance theory?
options: That it was developed too early
That it only applies to smoking
That Festinger did not do enough experiments
That it is broad and that people sometimes tolerate inconsistency
questions.explanation: The passage states that critics have noted the theory is broad and that people sometimes tolerate inconsistency without obvious discomfort.

questions.text: The author mentions consumer behaviour and political attitudes in order to
options: criticise the theory
argue that dissonance is increasing
explain Festinger's research method
give examples of areas where the theory has been applied
questions.explanation: The passage says dissonance theory has been used to study decisions about consumer behaviour, political attitudes, and moral behaviour.

passages.title: The Printing Press and the Spread of Ideas
passages.content:
The invention of the printing press in Europe in the mid-fifteenth century is often regarded as one of the most important developments in human history. Before the press, books were copied by hand, which was slow and expensive. Only a small number of people had access to written works.

Johannes Gutenberg's press, which used movable type, made it possible to produce many copies of a text quickly and at lower cost. The first major book printed in this way was the Bible. Soon, printers across Europe were producing not only religious texts but also scientific works, political pamphlets, and literature. Ideas could spread much faster than before.

Scholars have argued that the printing press contributed to major social and intellectual movements. The Protestant Reformation, for example, relied on the wide distribution of Bibles and pamphlets so that people could read and interpret religious texts for themselves. Similarly, the scientific revolution was aided by the rapid exchange of research and ideas through printed books and letters. Literacy rates rose as more people had reason to learn to read.

Of course, the press did not act alone. Political, economic, and religious conditions in Europe shaped how and where printing spread. Nevertheless, the technology made it possible for ideas to reach a far wider audience than ever before, with lasting effects on education, religion, and politics.

questions.text: What is the passage mainly about?
options: The life of Johannes Gutenberg
How the printing press changed the spread of ideas in Europe
The cost of books before and after the printing press
The role of the Bible in the Protestant Reformation
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on the invention of the printing press and its impact on the spread of ideas, including religion, science, and literacy.

questions.text: According to the passage, what was the first major book printed using Gutenberg's press?
options: A scientific work
A political pamphlet
The Bible
A literary text
questions.explanation: The passage states that the first major book printed in this way was the Bible.

questions.text: According to the passage, how did the printing press support the Protestant Reformation?
options: By making religious education compulsory
By enabling the wide distribution of Bibles and pamphlets
By reducing the power of the Catholic Church directly
By inventing movable type for religious texts only
questions.explanation: The passage says the Reformation relied on the wide distribution of Bibles and pamphlets so people could read and interpret religious texts for themselves.

questions.text: The author mentions that 'the press did not act alone' in order to
options: criticise the importance of the printing press
suggest that Gutenberg had many helpers
explain why literacy rates rose slowly
emphasise that other factors also influenced how printing spread
questions.explanation: The author acknowledges that political, economic, and religious conditions also shaped how and where printing spread, while still emphasising the technology's impact.

passages.title: Historical Causation and Multiple Factors
passages.content:
Historians rarely explain major change by pointing to a single cause. Instead, they look for multiple factors—economic, political, cultural, and technological—that interact over time. The decline of a dynasty, the rise of industrialisation, or the spread of a new religion can seldom be attributed to one event or one person.

For instance, the fall of the Roman Empire in the West has been explained by military pressure at the borders, economic strain, political instability, and cultural shifts. No single factor is sufficient on its own; historians debate how to weigh each. Similarly, the Industrial Revolution in Britain depended on technological innovation, access to raw materials and capital, labour supply, and a legal and political environment that allowed investment and trade. Change in one area made change in others possible.

This approach does not mean that individual actions or events are unimportant. Rather, it means that they are understood within a broader context. Historians also distinguish between short-term triggers—a battle, a treaty, a discovery—and long-term causes that may have developed over decades or centuries. Understanding both helps explain why events unfolded as they did.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of the passage?
options: To argue that single causes are more important than multiple causes
To explain how historians use multiple factors to explain major change
To describe the fall of the Roman Empire in detail
To compare the Roman Empire and the Industrial Revolution
questions.explanation: The passage explains that historians look for multiple interacting factors rather than a single cause when explaining major change.

questions.text: According to the passage, which of the following has been cited as a factor in the fall of the Roman Empire in the West?
options: The invention of the printing press
Military pressure at the borders
The Protestant Reformation
British industrialisation
questions.explanation: The passage lists military pressure at the borders, economic strain, political instability, and cultural shifts as factors used to explain the fall.

questions.text: According to the passage, how do historians often view short-term triggers?
options: As more important than long-term causes
As unrelated to long-term causes
As part of a broader context that includes long-term causes
As the only true causes of change
questions.explanation: The passage says historians distinguish between short-term triggers and long-term causes and that understanding both helps explain events.

questions.text: The author uses the Industrial Revolution in Britain to illustrate
options: that technology alone caused the revolution
that historians disagree about everything
that short-term triggers are sufficient
that multiple factors—technology, materials, capital, labour, law—interacted
questions.explanation: The passage uses the Industrial Revolution as an example of change depending on technological, economic, and political factors that interacted.

passages.title: Renaissance Art and Perspective
passages.content:
During the Renaissance, artists in Italy and elsewhere in Europe began to use new techniques to create a sense of depth on a flat surface. One of the most important was linear perspective. By drawing lines that converge at a single point on the horizon—the vanishing point—artists could make a painting look like a window into a real space.

Before this period, many paintings had a flatter, more symbolic style. Figures might be sized by importance rather than by their position in space. Renaissance artists studied geometry and optics to represent the world more as the eye sees it. Buildings, tiles, and roads could be drawn so that they appeared to recede into the distance.

The technique was used in religious and secular works alike. It gave viewers the feeling that they could step into the scene. Linear perspective became a standard tool for Western art for centuries and influenced how people thought about space and representation.

questions.text: What is the passage mainly about?
options: The history of Italy during the Renaissance
The use of linear perspective in Renaissance art to create depth
The difference between religious and secular painting
The importance of geometry in education
questions.explanation: The passage focuses on how Renaissance artists used linear perspective to create a sense of depth on a flat surface.

questions.text: According to the passage, what is the vanishing point?
options: A type of paint used by Renaissance artists
The most important figure in a painting
A technique for painting faces
A point on the horizon where lines converge in perspective
questions.explanation: The passage states that artists drew lines that converge at a single point on the horizon—the vanishing point.

questions.text: According to the passage, how might figures have been sized in art before the Renaissance?
options: By their position in space
By importance rather than position in space
By the same size as in real life
By the viewer's distance
questions.explanation: The passage says that before this period, figures might be sized by importance rather than by their position in space.

questions.text: The passage suggests that linear perspective
options: was only used in Italy
was replaced quickly by photography
was used only for religious works
became a standard tool in Western art for centuries
questions.explanation: The passage states that linear perspective became a standard tool for Western art for centuries.

passages.title: Impressionism and the Shift to Modern Art
passages.content:
Impressionism, which emerged in France in the 1860s and 1870s, broke with the academic tradition that had dominated European painting. Instead of carefully finished surfaces and historical or mythological subjects, Impressionist painters often worked outdoors, capturing the effects of light and atmosphere at a particular moment. Brushwork became more visible; colour was often applied in separate strokes that blended in the viewer's eye.

Artists such as Monet, Renoir, and Degas were initially rejected by the official Salon. They organised their own exhibitions and were criticised for their "unfinished" look and their choice of everyday subjects—street scenes, cafés, gardens. Critics argued that the works lacked the finish and moral seriousness of academic art. Over time, however, the movement gained acceptance and influenced later developments in modern art.

The emphasis on light, colour, and the perception of the moment also reflected broader changes in nineteenth-century culture, including the rise of photography and new theories of vision. Impressionism is now seen as a bridge between the realist tradition and the more radical experiments of the twentieth century.

questions.text: What is the passage mainly about?
options: The history of the Salon in France
Impressionism as a break from academic tradition and its focus on light and moment
The biographies of Monet, Renoir, and Degas
The invention of photography
questions.explanation: The passage describes Impressionism's break with academic tradition and its focus on light, atmosphere, and the moment.

questions.text: According to the passage, how did Impressionist painters often work?
options: Only in studios
From memory only
Outdoors, capturing effects of light and atmosphere
Only with historical subjects
questions.explanation: The passage states that Impressionist painters often worked outdoors, capturing the effects of light and atmosphere at a particular moment.

questions.text: According to the passage, why were Impressionist works initially criticised?
options: For being too dark
For their "unfinished" look and everyday subjects
For being too large
For using only black and white
questions.explanation: The passage says they were criticised for their "unfinished" look and their choice of everyday subjects.

questions.text: The author describes Impressionism as a 'bridge' in order to
options: compare it to a physical bridge
suggest it was only a short-lived movement
explain why it was rejected at first
emphasise its connection between realist tradition and later modern art
questions.explanation: The passage states that Impressionism is now seen as a bridge between the realist tradition and the more radical experiments of the twentieth century.

passages.title: Supply and Demand
passages.content:
In a market economy, prices are largely determined by supply and demand. Demand refers to how much of a good or service consumers are willing and able to buy at different prices. Generally, when the price goes down, demand goes up. Supply refers to how much producers are willing and able to sell at different prices. Usually, when the price goes up, supply goes up, because higher prices give producers an incentive to produce more.

The point where supply and demand meet is called the equilibrium. At the equilibrium price, the quantity that producers want to sell equals the quantity that consumers want to buy. If the price is above equilibrium, there is a surplus: more is supplied than demanded. If the price is below equilibrium, there is a shortage: more is demanded than supplied. In both cases, market forces tend to push the price toward equilibrium.

This model is a simplification. In reality, other factors—such as government rules, taxes, or the number of competitors—also affect prices. Still, the idea of supply and demand helps explain why prices change when conditions in the market change.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of the passage?
options: To argue that government should control prices
To explain how supply and demand affect prices in a market
To compare different types of markets
To recommend that producers increase supply
questions.explanation: The passage explains how supply and demand determine prices and describes equilibrium, surplus, and shortage.

questions.text: According to the passage, what happens at the equilibrium price?
options: The quantity producers want to sell equals the quantity consumers want to buy
Supply is zero
Demand is at its highest
Prices begin to fall
questions.explanation: The passage states that at the equilibrium price, the quantity that producers want to sell equals the quantity that consumers want to buy.

questions.text: According to the passage, what typically happens when the price is above equilibrium?
options: A shortage occurs
Demand increases
A surplus occurs
Supply decreases
questions.explanation: The passage says that if the price is above equilibrium, there is a surplus: more is supplied than demanded.

questions.text: The passage notes that the supply-and-demand model is a simplification because
options: prices never change
consumers never respond to prices
equilibrium does not exist in reality
other factors such as government rules and competition also affect prices
questions.explanation: The passage states that in reality, other factors—such as government rules, taxes, or the number of competitors—also affect prices.

passages.title: Externalities and Market Failure
passages.content:
When a market transaction affects people who are not directly involved in the transaction, economists call this an externality. If a factory pollutes a river, the cost of the pollution may be borne by people who live downstream—they are not part of the sale of the factory's product, but they are harmed. This is a negative externality. The market price of the product does not include this social cost, so the factory may produce more than is socially desirable.

Positive externalities also exist. Education, for example, benefits not only the person who receives it but also society through a more skilled workforce and lower crime. If individuals do not take these broader benefits into account, they may invest less in education than would be optimal for society as a whole.

When externalities are significant, markets may fail to allocate resources efficiently. Governments often respond with taxes, subsidies, or regulations. A tax on pollution can make the producer bear part of the social cost; a subsidy for education can encourage more investment. Economists debate how much intervention is appropriate, but the concept of externalities helps explain why unregulated markets do not always lead to the best outcome for society.

questions.text: What is the passage mainly about?
options: How to run a factory without pollution
Externalities—when market transactions affect third parties—and possible policy responses
The benefits of education for individuals only
Why markets always work well
questions.explanation: The passage defines externalities (positive and negative), explains how they can lead to market failure, and mentions policy responses.

questions.text: According to the passage, why may a polluting factory produce more than is socially desirable?
options: Because demand is very high
Because the government requires it
Because downstream residents buy the product
Because the market price does not include the social cost of pollution
questions.explanation: The passage states that the market price of the product does not include the social cost, so the factory may produce more than is socially desirable.

questions.text: According to the passage, how can a subsidy for education address a positive externality?
options: By reducing the cost of pollution
By replacing private schools
By taxing those who do not study
By encouraging more investment in education than individuals might choose alone
questions.explanation: The passage says that if individuals do not take broader benefits into account they may invest less than optimal, and a subsidy for education can encourage more investment.

questions.text: The author mentions that 'economists debate how much intervention is appropriate' in order to
options: reject all government intervention
argue that taxes are always best
explain why externalities are rare
indicate that the extent of policy response is contested
questions.explanation: The passage acknowledges debate over how much intervention is appropriate while still explaining why externalities justify some policy response.

passages.title: How Batteries Store Energy
passages.content:
A battery stores chemical energy and converts it into electrical energy when it is connected to a device. Inside a typical battery are two electrodes—a positive and a negative—and a substance called an electrolyte between them. When the battery is used, a chemical reaction occurs: electrons flow from the negative electrode through the external circuit to the positive electrode, while ions move through the electrolyte. This flow of electrons is the electric current that powers the device.

When a rechargeable battery is charged, the reaction is reversed. Energy from an external source pushes electrons and ions back, restoring the chemical state of the battery so it can be used again. The amount of energy a battery can store depends on the materials used and the design. Over time, repeated charging and discharging can reduce a battery's capacity because the materials degrade.

Batteries are used in everything from phones and laptops to electric vehicles and grid storage. Research continues into materials that can store more energy, last longer, and be made from more abundant or less harmful substances.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of the passage?
options: To compare different brands of batteries
To explain how batteries store and convert energy
To argue that all devices should use batteries
To describe the history of the battery
questions.explanation: The passage explains how a battery stores chemical energy, converts it to electrical energy, and how rechargeable batteries work.

questions.text: According to the passage, what flows through the external circuit when a battery is used?
options: Ions
Electrolyte
Electrons
Chemical energy
questions.explanation: The passage states that electrons flow from the negative electrode through the external circuit to the positive electrode.

questions.text: According to the passage, why can repeated charging and discharging reduce a battery's capacity?
options: Because the electrolyte evaporates
Because the voltage increases
Because the device uses more power
Because the materials degrade
questions.explanation: The passage says that over time, repeated charging and discharging can reduce capacity because the materials degrade.

questions.text: The passage suggests that current research on batteries aims to
options: phase out all batteries
use only non-rechargeable batteries
eliminate the need for electrolytes
find materials that store more energy, last longer, and may be less harmful
questions.explanation: The passage states that research continues into materials that can store more energy, last longer, and be made from more abundant or less harmful substances.

passages.title: Integrating Renewable Energy into the Grid
passages.content:
Electricity grids were designed for power that can be adjusted to match demand. Traditional power plants—coal, gas, nuclear—can increase or decrease output as needed. Wind and solar power, by contrast, depend on the weather. The sun does not shine at night; the wind does not always blow. This variability poses a challenge for grid operators who must keep supply and demand in balance at all times.

To integrate more renewable energy, grids need flexibility. One approach is to use energy storage, such as large batteries or pumped hydro, to store excess renewable power when supply is high and release it when supply is low. Another is to improve connections between regions so that surplus power in one area can be sent to another. Demand response—in which consumers reduce or shift their use when the grid is under stress—also helps.

No single solution is sufficient. Grids will likely combine storage, transmission, and demand management. The transition to higher shares of renewable energy also requires changes in market rules and planning, so that the system remains reliable and affordable as the mix of generation changes.

questions.text: What is the passage mainly about?
options: The history of electricity grids
The challenge of variable wind and solar power and how grids can integrate more renewables
Why coal and nuclear power are better than renewables
How to build more wind farms
questions.explanation: The passage describes the variability of renewables, the challenge for grid operators, and approaches such as storage, transmission, and demand response.

questions.text: According to the passage, why is wind and solar power more challenging for grid operators than traditional power plants?
options: Because their output depends on the weather and cannot be adjusted to match demand
Because they are more expensive to build
Because they produce too much power
Because they are located far from cities
questions.explanation: The passage states that wind and solar depend on the weather and that this variability poses a challenge for keeping supply and demand in balance.

questions.text: According to the passage, which of the following is mentioned as a way to integrate more renewable energy?
options: Building only solar plants
Eliminating demand response
Using only one region for generation
Using energy storage to store excess power and release it when needed
questions.explanation: The passage says one approach is to use energy storage to store excess renewable power when supply is high and release it when supply is low.

questions.text: The passage suggests that the transition to more renewable energy requires
options: only better batteries
no change to existing grids
reducing demand only
changes in market rules and planning as well as technical solutions
questions.explanation: The passage states that the transition requires changes in market rules and planning so that the system remains reliable and affordable.
